{{refimprove|date=March 2008}}
'''Gel''' ('''Good Experience Live''') is a conference focused on the concept of a "good experience" in all contexts – business, art, society, technology, and life.
The conference has been held annually in [[New York City]] since 2003, and the first European counterpart, euroGel 2006, took place in [[Copenhagen]], on 1 September 2006. Each conference has been hosted by Gel's founder, Mark Hurst. Past speakers have included [[Salman Khan]],<ref>[https://www.khanacademy.org/talks-and-interviews/other-features/v/salman-khan-speaks-at-gel--good-experience-live--conference Khan Academy] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140412034336/http://www.khanacademy.org/talks-and-interviews/other-features/v/salman-khan-speaks-at-gel--good-experience-live--conference |date=2014-04-12 }}</ref> [[Gabriel Weinberg]],<ref>[http://www.xconomy.com/new-york/2013/04/23/duckduckgo-pushes-its-privacy-geared-search-engine-at-gel-conference/ Xconomy]</ref> and [[Bob Mankoff]].<ref>[http://www.ixda.org/node/16341 IXDA] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20140411142841/http://www.ixda.org/node/16341 |date=2014-04-11 }}</ref>
GEL 2013 took place April 17–19, 2013 in New York City.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.gelconference.com/ Gel's website]
[[Category:Conferences]] [[Category:Recurring events established in 2003]]

{{Infobox academic | honorific_prefix =Doctor | name = Helga Nowotny | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = File:Helga Nowotny World Economic Forum 2013.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Nowotny at the [[World Economic Forum]] Annual Meeting in 2013 | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1937||}} | birth_place = Vienna, Austria | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | region = | nationality =Austrian | period = | occupation = Professor at [[ETH Zurich]] | title = Professor emeritus | boards = [[European Research Advisory Board of the European Commission]] (Chair, 2001-2006)
Governing Board of the [[University of Goettingen]] (Vice-Chair)
[[ERC Scientific Council]] (President, 2010-2013)
Scientific Advisory Board of the [[University of Vienna]] (Chair, current) Governing Board of the Science Center in Berlin (current) | known_for = | spouse = | children = | signature = | signature_alt = | signature_size = | era = | discipline = Law, [[Sociology]] | sub_discipline = Social studies of science, science and society and social time | movement = | religion = | denomination = | education =[[University of Vienna]] | alma_mater = [[Columbia University]] | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | main_interests = | workplaces = [[Vienna Science and Technology Fund]]
[[King's College, Cambridge|King’s College]]
[[University of Bielefeld]]
[[Wissenschaftszentrum Berlin]]
[[School for Advanced Studies in the Social Sciences]] | notable_works = | notable_ideas = | influences = | influenced = | awards = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Helga Nowotny''' (born 1937{{cite LAF|id=n83-62721}}) is Professor emeritus of [[Sociology of science and technology|Social Studies of Science]], [[ETH Zurich]]. She has held numerous leadership roles on Academic boards and public policy councils, and she has authored many publications the social studies of science and technology.{{Cite web|title = NOWOTNY Helga|url = https://erc.europa.eu/organisation/helga-nowotny|website = ERC: European Research Council|accessdate = 2015-12-14|publisher = European Research Council}} == Early life == Nowotny grew up in [[Vienna|Vienna, Austria]] during [[World War II]]. In interviews, she has recalled first wanting to become a scientist at the age of 8, when she was sent to [[Vorarlberg]], the westernmost province of Austria, and quickly learned the local dialect.{{Cite web|title = Interview: Helga Nowotny, ERC President|url = http://eandt.theiet.org/magazine/2011/06/qanda-Helga-novotny.cfm|website = The Engineering and Technology Magazine|accessdate = 2015-12-14|last = Burrows|first = Erika|last2 = Vitaliev|first2 = Vitali|date = 13 Jun 2011|publisher = The Institution of Engineering and Technology}} Nowotny received her [[Juris Doctor|doctorate of jurisprudence]] at the [[University of Vienna]] in 1959. After completing her degree, she faced opposition to her application for an assistant professorship in the Department of Criminology there on the basis of her being a woman. She agreed with the hiring professor that if a more capable man applied for the position, he could have the job. In the end, she was hired to the position.{{Cite web|title = Helga Nowotny, President of the ERC: "Europe must regain its confidence through science"|url = http://www.kuleuven.be/english/news/2012/LIF/meet-the-honourees/interviews/helga-nowotny-president-of-the-european-research-council-europe-must-regain-its-confidence-through-science|website = KU Leuven|accessdate = 2015-12-14|publisher = KU Leuven}} It was there that she became interested in the sociology of science. In 1965, she moved to [[New York City]] with her husband, where she enrolled in a sociology doctoral program. There, she met [[Paul Lazarsfeld]] and [[Robert K. Merton]], who mentored her throughout her education.{{cite journal|last1=Nowotny|first1=Helga|last2=Leroy|first2=Pieter|title=Helga Nowotny: an itinerary between sociology of knowledge and public debate|journal=Natures Sciences Sociétés|volume=17|issue=1|year=2009|pages=57–64|issn=1240-1307|doi=10.1051/nss/2009010}} In 1969, Nowotny earned her Ph.D. in [[sociology]] at [[Columbia University]], [[New York City|New York]], where she completed her thesis on [[macrosociology]] and its methodology. She returned to Vienna to work as an Associate Professor at the [[Institute for Advanced Studies (Vienna)|Institute for Advanced Studies]]. ==Research and publications== Nowotny's work in the 1970s and 1980s includes topics such as scientific controversies and technological [[risk]]s, social time, coping with [[uncertainty]], self-organization in science and [[gender]] relations in science, resulting in major monographs, co-edited and edited books and numerous articles. In 1989, she published the book ''Eigenzeit'' (English title: ''Time: The Modern and Postmodern Experience),'' which has since been translated into several languages.{{Cite web|title = Helga Nowotny awarded honorary doctorate|url = http://www.uib.no/en/svf/92065/helga-nowotny-awarded-honorary-doctorate|website = University of Bergen Faculty of Social Sciences|accessdate = 2015-12-14|publisher = University of Bergen|date = 3 Oct 2015}} Between 1992 and 1995 Helga Nowotny has been President of the [[International Society for the Study of Time]]. From the 1990s onwards she focused her research activities on new topics in [[sociology of science and technology|social studies of science and technology]]. She conducted an empirical study on the discovery of high-superconductivity research and its impact on research policy (with [[Ulrike Felt]]) and increasingly on the changing relationship between [[science]] and [[society]]. In 1994 Nowotny helped coin the term “Mode 2” for a new mode of applied research focused on solving specific problems. By contrast, “Mode 1” is basic research done within disciplines, initiated by the interest of the investigator, not from external demand.{{Cite web|title = Helga Nowotny, new president of European Research Council|url = http://www.en.globaltalentnews.com/current_news/reports/3123/Helga-Nowotny-new-president-of-European-Research-Council.html|website = www.en.globaltalentnews.com|accessdate = 2015-12-14|publisher = GT Media}} ==Research policy== [[File:Helga Nowotny 01.JPG|left|thumb|Nowotny at a public speaking event in December 2015.]] Next to her teaching and research activities, carried out at several universities and research institutions in Europe, Nowotny had always been intensely engaged in research policy. From 1985-1992 she was Chair of the Standing Committee for the [[Social Sciences]] of the [[European Science Foundation]]. She has been chair and member of the scientific advisory boards of numerous research institutions and policy-related committees throughout Europe. From 2001 until early 2006 she was Chair of [[EURAB]], the European Research Advisory Board of the European Commission. Nowotny is one of the founding members of the [[European Research Council]], which has been established to fund frontier research at EU level based on the sole criteria of scientific excellence and pan-European competition. There she served as the Vice President and in February 2010, Nowotny was unanimously elected to the position of President of the [[European Research Council]] after the resignation of the founding president, [[Fotis Kafatos]].{{Cite web|title = European Research Council Elects New President: Helga Nowotny|url = http://news.sciencemag.org/2010/02/european-research-council-elects-new-president-helga-nowotny|website = ScienceMag News|accessdate = 2015-12-14|last = Vogel|first = Gretchen|date = 19 Feb 2010|publisher = American Association for the Advancement of Science}}{{Cite web|title = Prof. Helga Nowotny appointed as new President of the European Research Council|url = http://epws.org/prof-helga-nowotny-appointed-as-new-president-of-the-european-research-council/|website = European Platform of Women Scientists|accessdate = 2015-12-14|publisher = European Platform of Women Scientists EPWS|date = 22 Feb 2010}} As president of the ERC, she promoted increases in research funding across Europe, and advised new EU member states to increase funding support for their own research programs to prevent a "[[Brain-drain|brain drain]]".{{Cite web|title = ERC stands firm on excellence: to get more grants, newer EU members need to try harder|url = http://www.sciencebusiness.net/news/75660/ERC-stands-firm-on-excellence-to-get-more-grants-newer-EU-members-need-to-try-harder|website = www.sciencebusiness.net|accessdate = 2015-12-14|publisher = Business Publishing Ltd.|last = Koekoek|first = Peter}} She held the position until December 2013. In 2014, she was appointed chair of the ERA Council Forum Austria, which advises the Austrian Ministry of Science and Research at the interface of European and national research policy.{{Cite web|title = Helga Nowotny - Princeton-Fung Global Forum|url = http://www.princeton.edu/fungforum/2014/speakers/helga-nowotny/|website = Princeton University|accessdate = 2015-12-14|publisher = The Trustees of Princeton University}} Currently, Nowotny is Chair of the International Advisory Board of the University of Vienna.{{Citation needed|date = December 2015}} == Professional positions == In 1981-1982 and 2003-2004 Nowotny was a Fellow at the [[Wissenschaftskolleg zu Berlin]] and from 1992-1999 Permanent Fellow at [[Collegium Budapest]]/Institute of Advanced Study. Before moving to [[ETH Zurich]], she was Professor and Head of the newly founded Institute for Theory and Social Studies of Science of the [[University of Vienna]]. From 1998 on, Nowotny was Director of the Collegium Helveticum at ETH Zurich. She was the founding director of the post-graduate fellowship programme based at ETH “Society in science: the [[Branco Weiss]] Fellowship” until 2004, when she returned to her native Vienna. From 2008 to 2014, Nowotny was a member of the Holberg Committee, which awards the Holberg prize to scholars who have made outstanding contributions to research in the arts and humanities, social sciences, law or theology. Nowotny has held teaching and research positions at the Institute of Advanced Study in Vienna, [[King's College, Cambridge]], UK, the [[University of Bielefeld]], the [[Wissenschaftszentrum Berlin]] and the [[École des Hautes Études en Sciences Sociales]] in Paris. Nowotny is vice president of the council for the [[Lindau Nobel Laureate Meetings]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.lindau-nobel.org/about/|title=About|work=The Lindau Nobel Laureate Meetings|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en-US}} == Awards and prizes == Nowotny is a Member of [[Academia Europaea]] and Foreign Member of the [[Royal Swedish Academy of Sciences]] since 2006. Among other honours she has been awarded the [[J.D. Bernal]] Prize for her lifelong achievements in [[Sociology of science and technology|social studies of science]]. In October 2015, she received an [[Honorary degree|honorary doctorate]] at the [[University of Bergen]].{{Cite web|title = Helga Nowotny appointed as honorary doctor at UiB {{!}} Holbergprisen|url = http://holbergprisen.no/en/news/holberg-prize/helga-nowotny-utnevnt-til-resdoktor-ved-uib|website = Holberg Prize|accessdate = 2015-12-14|publisher = Holbergprisen - Universitetet i Bergen|date = 7 Jun 2015}} She has also received an honorary doctorate from the [[Weizmann Institute of Science]] and the [[University of Twente]].{{Cite web|title = Professor Helga Nowotny honorary doctor of the University of Twente|url = https://www.utwente.nl/bms/steps/news/archive/honorary_doctorate_helga_nowotny/|website = www.utwente.nl|accessdate = 2015-12-14}} In September 2017, she was awarded the [[President's Medal (British Academy)|President's Medal]] of the [[British Academy]] "for her contribution to the founding and shaping of the European Research Council, and positively influencing the shape of research funding and research policy in the UK and Europe".{{cite web|title=From Wikipedia to Roman coins: British Academy recognises excellence in the humanities and social sciences|url=https://www.britac.ac.uk/news/wikipedia-roman-coins-british-academy-recognises-excellence-humanities-and-social-sciences|website=The British Academy|accessdate=5 October 2017}} == Selected bibliography == === Books === * {{cite book | last1 = Nowotny | first1 = Helga | last2 = Mendelsohn | first2 = Everett | title = Nineteen eighty-four: science between utopia and dystopia | publisher = [[Springer Science+Business Media|D. Reidel Publishg Co.]] | location = Dordrecht Boston Hingham, Massachusetts | year = 1984 | isbn = 9789027717214 }} * {{cite book | last1 = Nowotny | first1 = Helga | title = The new production of knowledge: the dynamics of science and research in contemporary societies | publisher = SAGE Publications | location = London Thousand Oaks, California | year = 1994 | isbn = 9780803977945 |display-authors=etal}} * {{cite book | last1 = Nowotny | last2 = Taschwer | first2 = Klaus | title = The sociology of the sciences | publisher = E. Elgar | location = Cheltenham, UK Brookfield, Vermont, US | year = 1996 | isbn = 9781852789114 }} [http://www.gbv.de/dms/goettingen/239157532.pdf Pdf of book contents.] * {{cite book | last1 = Nowotny | first1 = Helga | last2 = Scott | first2 = Peter | last3 = Gibbons | first3 = Michael | author-link2 = Peter Scott (educationalist) | title = Re-thinking science: knowledge and the public in an age of uncertainty | publisher = Polity | location = Cambridge, UK | year = 2001 | isbn = 9780745626086 }} * {{cite book | last = Nowotny | first = Helga | title = The public nature of science under assault politics, markets, science and the law | publisher = [[Springer Science+Business Media|Springer]] | location = Berlin New York | year = 2005 | isbn = 9783540257912 }} * {{cite conference| last = Nowotny | first = Helga |date= 2006 |title= Cultures of technology and the quest for innovation |pages= |location= New York, New York | publisher = Berghahn Books | isbn = 9781845451172 }} Conference details: ''Cultures of technology and the quest for innovation, Kulturwissenschaftliches Institut (KWI) in Essen, Germany, April 2003.'' * {{cite book | last = Nowotny | first = Helga | title = Insatiable curiosity: innovation in a fragile future | publisher = [[MIT Press]] | location = Cambridge, Massachusetts | year = 2008 | isbn = 9781435654976 }} * {{cite book | last1 = Nowotny | first1 = Helga | last2 = Testa | first2 = Giuseppe | title = Naked genes: reinventing the human in the molecular age | publisher = [[MIT Press]] | location = Cambridge, Massachusetts | year = 2010 | isbn = 9780262014939 }} === Journal articles === * {{Cite journal | last = Nowotny | first = Helga | title = Time and social theory: towards a social theory of time | journal = [[Time & Society]] | volume = 1 | issue = 3 | pages = 421–454 | publisher = [[Sage Publications|Sage]] | doi = 10.1177/0961463X92001003006 | date = September 1992 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0961463X92001003006 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} * {{Cite journal | last = Nowotny | first = Helga | title = Socially distributed knowledge: five spaces for science to meet the public | journal = [[Public Understanding of Science]] | volume = 2 | issue = 4 | pages = 307–319 | publisher = [[Sage Publications|Sage]] | doi = 10.1088/0963-6625/2/4/002 | date = October 1993 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1088/0963-6625/2/4/002 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} * {{Cite journal | last = Nowotny | first = Helga | title = The place of people in our knowledge | journal = [[European Review]] | volume = 7 | issue = 2 | pages = 247–262 | publisher = [[Cambridge University Press|Cambridge Journals]] | doi = 10.1017/S1062798700004026 | date = May 1999 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1017/S1062798700004026 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} * {{Cite journal | last = Nowotny | first = Helga | title = Transgressive competence: the narrative of expertise | journal = [[European Journal of Social Theory]] | volume = 3 | issue = 1 | pages = 5–21 | publisher = [[Sage Publications|Sage]] | doi = 10.1177/136843100003001001 | date = February 2000 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1177/136843100003001001 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} * {{Cite journal | last = Nowotny | first = Helga | title = Democratising expertise and socially robust knowledge | journal = Science and Public Policy | volume = 30 | issue = 3 | pages = 151–156 | publisher = [[Oxford University Press|Oxford Journals]] | date = June 2003 | url = http://spp.oxfordjournals.org/content/30/3/151.short | ref = harv | postscript = . | doi=10.3152/147154303781780461}} * {{Cite journal | last = Nowotny | first = Helga | title = The increase of complexity and its reduction: emergent interfaces between the natural sciences, humanities and social sciences | journal = [[Theory, Culture & Society]] | volume = 22 | issue = 5 | pages = 15–31 | publisher = [[Sage Publications|Sage]] | doi = 10.1177/0263276405057189 | date = October 2005 | url = https://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0263276405057189 | ref = harv | postscript = . }} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.helga-nowotny.eu Personal homepage] *[http://erc.europa.eu ERC homepage] *{{worldcat id|lccn-n83-62721}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nowotny, Helga}} [[Category:Austrian sociologists]] [[Category:Sociology of science]] [[Category:1937 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Members of Academia Europaea]] [[Category:Members of the {{Infobox journal | cover = | editor = Nalin Surie | discipline = [[Political science]] | former_names = | abbreviation = | publisher = [[SAGE Publications]] | country =India | frequency = Quarterly | history = 1954 | openaccess = | license = | impact = | impact-year = | website = http://iqq.sagepub.com/ | link1 = http://iqq.sagepub.com/content/current | link1-name = Online access | link2 = http://iqq.sagepub.com/content/by/year | link2-name = Online archive | JSTOR = | OCLC = | LCCN = | CODEN = | ISSN = 0974-9284 | eISSN = 0975-2684 }}
'''''India Quarterly''''' is a [[peer review]]ed journal. This is forum for discussion on matters concerning international relations and national foreign policies. It is published quarterly by [http://www.sagepub.in/home.nav SAGE Publications] in association with [[Indian Council of World Affairs]].
This journal is a member of the [[Committee on Publication Ethics]] (COPE).
== Abstracting and indexing == ''India Quarterly'' is abstracted and indexed in: * [[Research Papers in Economics ]] * [[DeepDyve]] * [[Portico (service)|Portico]] * [[Dutch-KB]] * [[OCLC]] * [[Indian Citation Index|ICI]] * [[EBSCO]]: Australia/New Zealand Reference Centre * [[ProQuest]]: Worldwide Political Science Abstracts * ProQuest: Political Affairs Information Service * [[Thomson Reuters]]: [[Emerging Sources Citation Index]] (ESCI) * [[Scopus]] * [[J-Gate]]
==References== * http://www.icwa.in/ * http://publicationethics.org/members/india-quarterly-journal-international-affairs
==External links== * {{official website|http://iqq.sagepub.com}} * [http://www.sagepub.in/journals/Journal201957?#tabview=title=Journal Homepage]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=May 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2018}} {{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = Info-communications Media Development Authority |abbreviation = IMDA |logo = |formed = {{Start date|df=y|2016|10|1}} |preceding1 = Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore (IDA);
Media Development Authority (MDA) |jurisdiction = [[Government of Singapore]] |budget = $34 million [[SGD]] (2011) {{Better source|date=December 2013|reason=this figure is outdated and no citations are available}} |headquarters = 10 Pasir Panjang Road. #03-01 Mapletree Business City. Singapore 117438 |chief1_name = Chan Yeng Kit |chief1_position = Chairman |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |chief3_name = Jacqueline Poh |chief3_position = managing director |parent_agency = [[Ministry of Communications and Information]] |website = {{url|imda.gov.sg}} |seal=|employees=|chief4_name=|chief4_position=|chief5_name=|chief5_position=|chief6_name=|chief6_position=|chief7_name=|chief7_position=|chief8_name=|chief8_position=|chief9_name=|chief9_position=|parent_department=}} The '''Info-communications Media Development Authority''' ([[Abbreviation]]: '''IMDA''') is a [[Statutory boards of the Singapore Government|statutory board]] of the [[Government of Singapore|Singapore government]], under the [[Ministry of Communications and Information]] (MCI). The IMDA was officially formed on 1 October 2016, with the restructuring of the Media Development Authority (MDA) and Infocomm Development Authority (IDA),{{cite web|title=IDA, MDA to be restructured to capitalise on converging media and ICT landscape|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/ida-mda-to-be/2433768.html|publisher=Channel NewsAsia|accessdate=23 January 2016}}{{cite web|title=GovTech about using technology to create citizen-centric solutions: CEO|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/business/govtech-about-using/2740916.html|publisher=Channel NewsAsia|accessdate=28 May 2016}} and officially legislated in Parliament on 18 August 2016.{{cite web|title=Parliament passes Info-communications Media Development Authority Bill|url=http://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/parliament-passes-info/3048966.html|publisher=Channel NewsAsia|accessdate=26 August 2016}} == History == The '''Infocomm Development Authority of Singapore''' (IDA) was formed earlier in 1999 when the government merged the National Computer Board (NCB) and ''Telecommunication Authority of Singapore'' (TAS), as a result of a growing convergence of information technology and telephony. '''IDA''' is now split into '''GOVTECH''' [[Government Technology Agency]] and '''IMDA'''. The Media Development Authority (MDA) was set up in 2003, with the merger of the Singapore Broadcasting Authority, the Films and Publications Department and the Singapore Film Commission, to champion the development of a vibrant media sector in Singapore.{{cite web|title=Statutory Boards|url=http://www.mci.gov.sg/content/mci_corp/web/mci/statutoryboards.html|publisher=Mci.gov.sg|accessdate=1 December 2013}} == Smart Nation == IDA, along with the Smart Nation Program Office collaboratively work on Singapore's Smart Nation Program, https://www.smartnation.sg/ a national program to develop Singapore as a Smart Country. With the formation of GOVTECHhttps://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/parliament-bills-to-merge-ida-and-mda-and-to-form-new-govtech-agency-passed agency, it will continue to address key technologies needed to implement smart nation platform. The areas specifically addressed by the Smart Nation Program include: * Smart Healthhttps://www.smartnation.sg/apps/page/1#3 * Smart Transporthttps://www.smartnation.sg/apps/page/1#8 * Smart Homes ==Intelligent Nation 2015== IDA was in charge of the nation's 10-year infocomm masterplan, also known as [[IN2015|Intelligent Nation 2015]] (iN2015),{{cite web|title=Intelligent Nation 2015 (iN2015)|url=http://www.mci.gov.sg/content/mci_corp/web/mci/infocomm/developing_infocomm/masterplans/intelligent_nation2015in2015.html|publisher=Mci.gov.sg|accessdate=1 December 2013}} which has since been superseded by the Infocomm Media 2025 plan.{{Cite web|title = Infocomm Media 2025|url = http://www.mci.gov.sg/infocomm-media-2025|website = Ministry of Communications and Information|access-date = 2 February 2016}} Through iN2015, two key components introduced as part of the [[Next Generation National Infocomm Infrastructure]] (NGNII) initiative are, firstly, [[Wireless@SG]]—a wireless broadband programme developed by IDA{{cite web|title=Next Generation National Infocomm Infrastructure (Next Gen NII)|url=http://wiki.nus.edu.sg/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=19631393|publisher=Wiki.nus.edu.sg|accessdate=1 December 2013}}—and secondly, the Next Generation Nationwide Broadband Network (Next Gen NBN)—a nationwide ultra-high speed broadband network supporting speeds of up to 1Gbs targeted for completion in 2022.{{cite news|title=Pushing Singapore's ICT ahead to 2015|url=http://www.zdnet.com/pushing-singapores-ict-ahead-to-2015-2062051752/|publisher=ZDNet|accessdate=1 December 2013}} ==Programmes and initiatives== IDA oversaw and / or participated in a variety of programmes and initiatives across Singapore. A few of the key ones: *eCitizen portal, Gateway to all Singapore Government services *Infocomm Talent Portal, One-Stop Infocomm Educational and Career Resource Portal *Singapore’s e-Government website *e-Government Leadership Centre *Personal Data Protection Commission * 5G telecommunications & HetNet https://www.imda.gov.sg/regulations-licensing-and-consultations/frameworks-and-policies/spectrum-management-and-coordination * Singapore's Smart Nation Programhttps://www.imda.gov.sg/infocomm-and-media-news/whats-trending/2015/6/iot-and-the-smart-nation * Data Science and Data Analyticshttps://www.imda.gov.sg/about/newsroom/archived/ida/media-releases/2015/improving-lives-through-data-science-and-analytics * Sensor Networks & IoT https://www.imda.gov.sg/infocomm-and-media-news/whats-trending/2016/1/leading-the-charge-for-open-iot-standards * Smart Homeshttps://www.imda.gov.sg/infocomm-and-media-news/whats-trending/2014/6/smart-homes-can-lead-to-healthy-living * Green Data Center Programshttps://www.imda.gov.sg/infocomm-and-media-news/buzz-central/2015/5/greening-the-data-centre Student programmes offered include the National Infocomm Scholarship by the Scholarship Secretariat. ==Policies and regulations== *Consultation Papers & Decisions{{cite web|url=http://www.ida.gov.sg/~/media/Files/PCDG/Consultations/20150213_IPPeering/IPPeeringPublicConsult.pdf|format=PDF|title=The Internet Protocol Transit and Peering Landscape in Singapore|publisher=Ida.gov.sg|accessdate=19 September 2015}} ==Subsidiaries== IDA has four subsidiaries set up to perform specific functions that are beyond IDA's primary role and responsibilities. The subsidiaries are [[IDA International]],{{cite web|title=IDA International|url=http://www.idainternational.sg|publisher=Idainternational.sg|accessdate=1 December 2013}} IDA International official website, [[Infocomm Investments]] Pte Ltd (IIPL),{{cite web|title=Infocomm Investments|url=http://www.infocomminvestments.com|publisher=Infocomminvestments.com|accessdate=1 December 2013}} Singapore Network Information Centre ([[SGNIC]]), and [[Assurity Trusted Solutions]] Pte Ltd.{{cite news|title=S'pore government preps 2FA facility|url=http://www.zdnet.com/spore-government-preps-2fa-facility-2062206035/|publisher=ZDNet|accessdate=1 December 2013}} ==Criticism== Documents leaked as a result of a data breach, identified the IDC as a [[Hacking_Team#Customer_List|customer]] of the [[Hacking Team]] – a provider of intrusion and surveillance software to governments.{{cite news|title=Singapore's IDA reported to have dealings with spyware firm|url=http://www.theonlinecitizen.com/2015/07/singapores-ida-reported-to-have-dealings-with-spyware-firm/|accessdate=26 June 2016}} {{cite news|title=ingaporean and Malaysian Governments Accused of Using Spyware for Digital Surveillance of Citizens|url=http://www.ifsecglobal.com/the-singapore-and-malaysia-government-connection-with-hacking-team-exposed-both-countries-using-spyware-for-digital-surveillance/|accessdate=26 June 2016}} There are also some possible conflicts with which mainly concern the aspects of [[Net Neutrality]]:{{citations needed|reason=citation needed here|date=November 2017}} * [[Bandwidth throttling#Singapore|Bandwidth throttling]] * [[Deep packet inspection#Singapore|Deep packet inspection]] ==See also== * GOVTECH [[Government Technology Agency]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|https://www.ida.gov.sg/}} {{Government of Singapore}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Infocomm In Singapore}} [[Category:Infocomm in Singapore]] [[Category:Statutory boards of the Singapore Government]] [[Category:1999 establishments in Singapore]] [[Category:Communications authorities]]

revision.comment: /* Self-image/beauty standards */ Added link to a relevant Wikipedia article
revision.text:
'''Internalized racism''' is a form of [[internalized oppression]], defined by sociologist Karen D. Pyke as the "[[internalisation (sociology)|internalization]] of racial oppression by the racially subordinated."<ref name=":0">{{cite journal |last1=Pyke |first1=Karen D. |title=What is Internalized Racial Oppression and Why Don't We Study It? Acknowledging Racism's Hidden Injuries |journal=Sociological Perspectives |date=December 2010 |volume=53 |issue=4 |pages=551–572 |doi=10.1525/sop.2010.53.4.551}}</ref> In her study ''The Psychology of Racism, '' Robin Nicole Johnson emphasizes that internalized racism involves both "conscious and unconscious acceptance of a racial hierarchy in which whites are consistently ranked above [[People of color|People of Color]]."<ref>Robin Nicole Johnson ''The Psychology of Racism: How Internalized Racism, Academic Self-concept, and Campus Racial Climate Impact the Academic Experiences and Achievement of African American Undergraduates''</ref> These definitions encompass a wide range of instances, including, but not limited to, belief in negative racial stereotypes, adaptations to white cultural standards, and thinking that supports the status quo (i.e. denying that racism exists).<ref name=":1">{{cite journal |last1=Campón |first1=Rebecca Rangel |last2=Carter |first2=Robert T. |title=The Appropriated Racial Oppression Scale: Development and preliminary validation. |journal=Cultural Diversity and Ethnic Minority Psychology |date=2015 |volume=21 |issue=4 |pages=497–506 |doi=10.1037/cdp0000037|pmid=25894835 }}</ref>
Internalized racism as a phenomenon is a direct product of a racial classification system, and is found across different racial groups and regions around the world where [[Race (human categorization)|race]] exists as a [[Social constructionism|social construct]].<ref name=":0" /> In these places, internalized racism can have adverse effects on those who experience it. For example, high internalized racism scores have been linked to poor health outcomes among Caribbean black women, higher propensity for violence among African American young males, and increased domestic violence among Native American populations in the US.<ref name=":14">{{cite journal |last1=Mouzon |first1=Dawne M. |last2=McLean |first2=Jamila S. |title=Internalized racism and mental health among African-Americans, US-born Caribbean Blacks, and foreign-born Caribbean Blacks |journal=Ethnicity & Health |date=28 June 2016 |volume=22 |issue=1 |pages=36–48 |doi=10.1080/13557858.2016.1196652|pmid=27354264 }}</ref><ref name=":2">{{cite journal |last1=Bryant |first1=Wesley W. |title=Internalized Racism's Association With African American Male Youth's Propensity for Violence |journal=Journal of Black Studies |date=2011 |volume=42 |issue=4 |pages=690–707 |jstor=41151366 |pmid=21910273 }}</ref><ref name=":6">{{cite journal |last1=Poupart |first1=Lisa M. |title=The Familiar Face of Genocide: Internalized Oppression among American Indians |journal=Hypatia |date=2003 |volume=18 |issue=2 |pages=86–100 |jstor=3811013 }}</ref>
Responses to internalized racism have been varied. [[Internalized racism#Responses|Many of the approaches]] focus on dispelling false narratives learned from racial oppression. An example of opposition to internalized racism is the "[[Black is beautiful]]" cultural movement in the US, which sought to "directly attack [the] ideology" that blackness was ugly.<ref name=":17">{{Cite news|url=http://www.pbs.org/wnet/african-americans-many-rivers-to-cross/video/black-is-beautiful/|title=Black is Beautiful {{!}} Video {{!}} The African Americans: Many Rivers to Cross {{!}} PBS|work=The African Americans: Many Rivers to Cross|accessdate=2018-11-02}}</ref>
== Terminology and categorization == Although some definitions of internalized racism only include when racial [[stereotype]]s are internalized by the racial marginalized groups, internalized racism has been used to discuss much more than this.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Valenzuela|first=Angela|date=2010|title=Chapter 8: Uncovering Internalized Oppression|journal=Counterpoints|volume=356|pages=77–83|jstor=42980601}}</ref> The creators of the Appropriated Racial Oppression Scale (AROS) note that perhaps a more accurate phrase would be "appropriated racial oppression," because this distances the usage away from potentially "victim blaming" implications that the internalization of racist ideals and attitudes is due to some failure of the oppressed.<ref name=":1" /> Additionally, the term "[[Appropriation of knowledge|appropriation]]" indicates that internalized racism is learned from context, and therefore a product of [[socialization]] in a racialized society.
Alternatively, Bianchi, Zea, Belgrave, and Echeverry propose that internalized racism is a "state of racial self-conceptualization," conforming to racial oppression, as opposed to dissonance, resistance or the internalization of a positive racial identity.<ref name=":9" />
Internalized racism has also been referred to as [[indoctrination]] and [[Colonial mentality|mental colonization]].<ref name=":0" /> These phrases draw attention to the historical context of [[colonialism]] being used to create and maintain a system of [[White supremacy|white superiority]].
Internalized racism is also explored in the Nigrescence model, introduced by [[William E. Cross Jr.|William E. Cross]] in 1971. It explains how internalized racism in Black Americans involves the belief that white cultural values are superior than their own. Cross writes, “The driving force behind this need requires Afro-Americans to seek approval from whites in all activities, to use white expectations as the yardstick for determining what is good, desirable or necessary.” <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://psycnet.apa.org/record/1980-20869-001|title=PsycNET|website=psycnet.apa.org|accessdate=2018-10-15}}</ref> This conviction can be corrected when black individuals self-determine their identities apart from the influence of their white counterparts.
=== Dimensions === Scholars have picked different dimensions to categorize internalized racism. Psychologists David and Okazaki proposed that examples of internalized racism could be divided into the following: "internalized inferiority, feelings of shame and embarrassment, physical characteristics, within-group discrimination, and minimization or acceptance of oppression."<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Garcia|first=Gabriel M.|last2=David|first2=E. J. R.|last3=Mapaye|first3=Joy C.|date=2018-07-23|title=Internalized racial oppression as a moderator of the relationship between experiences of racial discrimination and mental distress among Asians and Pacific Islanders.|journal=Asian American Journal of Psychology|doi=10.1037/aap0000124|issn=1948-1993}}</ref> Alternatively, Campón and Carter use this list: "appropriations of negative stereotypes, thinking that maintains status quo (denying racism), adaptation to white cultural standards, devaluation of own group, and emotional reactions."<ref name=":1" /> These categories influence how scholars organize their measurements of internalized racism.<ref name=":1" />
=== Measures === Academics have attempted to create reliable measures of internalized racism, in order to test its [[Internalized racism#Implications|correlation to health outcomes]] and other variables of interest. Some examples of existing scales are the Nadanolitization (NAD) and Internalized Racial Oppression Scales (used for [[African Americans|Black Americans]]), the Colonial Mentality scale (used for [[Filipinos]]), and the Mochichua Tepehuani Scale (used for [[Chicano|Chicanx]]/[[Latino|Latinx]] populations).<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":1" /> The Appropriated Racial Oppression Scale (AROS) is designed as measure for all racial minorities.<ref name=":1" /> In the AROS, Campón and Carter use items such as "There have been times when I have been embarrassed to be a member of my race," "I would like for my children to have light skin," and "People take racial jokes too seriously" to assess an individual's level of internalized racism.<ref name=":1" />
== Manifestations == To explore the dimensions of internalized racism mentioned above, here are some of the ways in which scholars have observed the effects of internalized racism.[[File:Fair and Handsome - Skin-Whitening Product in Supermarket - Bandarawela - Hill Country - Sri Lanka (14122094934).jpg|thumb|Skin-Whitening Product in Sri Lankan Supermarket]] === Self-image/beauty standards === An empirical example of internalized racism is [[Kenneth_and_Mamie_Clark#Doll_experiments|Kenneth and Mamie Clark's doll experiment]], which was done in America at a time when black and white children were segregated. It involved an African-American child being presented with two dolls that were identical apart from skin and hair color, one doll being white with yellow hair and the other being brown with black hair. The child was asked which doll they would prefer to play with and why. All children in the study expressed a clear preference for the white doll.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.apa.org/research/action/segregation.aspx |title=Segregation Ruled Unequal, and Therefore Unconstitutional |publisher=Apa.org |date=2003-05-28 |accessdate=2013-11-19}}</ref>
In 2006 Kiri Davis recreated the experiment with 21 African-American preschool children for her documentary ''[[A Girl like Me (film)|A Girl Like Me]]''. Davis found that 15 of the children chose white dolls over black dolls, giving similar reasons as the original study subjects that associated white with "pretty" or "good" and black with "ugly" or "bad."<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/sectionfront/life/documentary-studies-renew-debate-about-skin-colors-impact-465158/ |title=Documentary, studies renew debate about skin color's impact - Pittsburgh Post-Gazette |publisher=Post-gazette.com |date=2006-12-26 |accessdate=2013-11-19}}</ref>
There is also an industry behind [[skin whitening]] products, which can be found from India to China to the United States. Because lighter skin is associated with desirable characteristics, people purchase such products in order to become lighter skinned.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2018/apr/23/skin-lightening-creams-are-dangerous-yet-business-is-booming-can-the-trade-be-stopped|title=Skin-lightening creams are dangerous – yet business is booming. Can the trade be stopped?|last=Khan|first=Coco|date=2018-04-23|website=the Guardian|accessdate=2018-11-02}}</ref>
=== Stereotype threat === [[Stereotype threat]] is a phenomenon studied in psychology in which members of a stigmatized group risk conforming to negative stereotypes through internalization of their validity.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pennington|first=Charlotte R.|last2=Heim|first2=Derek|last3=Levy|first3=Andrew R.|last4=Larkin|first4=Derek T.|date=2016-01-11|title=Twenty Years of Stereotype Threat Research: A Review of Psychological Mediators|journal=PLOS ONE|volume=11|issue=1|pages=e0146487|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0146487|issn=1932-6203|pmc=4713435|pmid=26752551}}</ref> In a 2018 study from Taylor, Garcia, Shelton and Yantis, note that both stereotype threat and a "black sheep effect" are products of internalized racism.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Taylor|first=Valerie Jones|last2=Garcia|first2=Randi L.|last3=Shelton|first3=J. Nicole|last4=Yantis|first4=Caitlyn|date=July 2018|title="A threat on the ground": The consequences of witnessing stereotype-confirming ingroup members in interracial interactions.|journal=Cultural Diversity and Ethnic Minority Psychology|volume=24|issue=3|pages=319–333|doi=10.1037/cdp0000190|pmid=29792484|issn=1939-0106}}</ref> Through being reminded of negative stereotypes associated with their race, participants responded with increased uncertainty, lower performance on tasks, and emotional reactions of anger and shame. They also sought to distance themselves from ingroup, stereotype confirming members, so as to avoid being targeted with negative generalizations.<ref name=":3" />
Stereotype threat from internalized racism goes beyond the individual. Those who experience internalized racism may end up projecting internalized negative attitudes onto others in their racial group. For example, teachers of color in the United States risk seeing their students through the lens of internalized racism.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Kohli|first=Rita|date=2013-11-07|title=Unpacking internalized racism: teachers of color striving for racially just classrooms|journal=Race Ethnicity and Education|volume=17|issue=3|pages=367–387|doi=10.1080/13613324.2013.832935|issn=1361-3324}}</ref> Because a teacher's expectations for a student's success can have empirical impacts on their educational outcomes, this puts students of color at an increased risk for impaired educational development.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Pygmalion in the classroom : teacher expectation and pupils' intellectual development|last=1933-|first=Rosenthal, Robert,|date=1992|publisher=Irvington Publishers|others=Jacobson, Lenore.|isbn=978-0829031539|edition= Newly expanded|location=New York|oclc=9080861}}</ref><ref name=":4" />
=== Intra/Interracial discrimination === Internalized racism manifests itself in both intraracial and inter[[racial discrimination]]. As an example of the intraracial case, Karen Pyke uses the term "defensive othering" to describe an individual or collective act of distancing oneself from members within one's own race that have a closer proximity to negative stereotypes.<ref name=":0" /> Defensive othering includes the use of the derogatory term "FOB" (short for "[[Fresh off the boat|Fresh Off the Boat]]") among Asian Americans. Although the racism towards newly arrived immigrants of Asian origin is neither the fault of the immigrants themselves or other Asian Americans, immigrants are often socially ostracized by members of their shared race because of internalized racism.<ref name=":0" />
In terms of interracial discrimination among the non-dominant racial groups, Robert E. Washington discusses "brown racism," his term for prejudice among non-black people of color towards black people, worldwide.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Washington|first=Robert E.|date=1990|title=Brown Racism and the Formation of a World System of Racial Stratification|journal=International Journal of Politics, Culture, and Society|volume=4|issue=2|pages=209–227|jstor=20006991}}</ref> With examples from Egypt, China, India and other regions, Washington notes that, through internalized racism, non-black people of color are reproducing white desirability and a devaluation of blackness. Internalized racism goes beyond negative attitudes and beliefs about one's own group: one can internalize racism directed towards other races as well.<ref name=":5" />
=== In education === The educational environment students are surrounded in can result in the development of internalized racism.<ref name=":4" /> When students from a minority group are placed in a school where the teachers and/or peers are majority white, the lack of diverse representation can produce feelings of inferiority. The perception of the majority group as superior can compel minority students to take on the cultural norms of that group in order to prevent alienation. Furthermore, the predominately white curriculum incorporated into the education system can give minority students the impression that only Eurocentric history is important. This further makes underrepresented students internalize that the history of their origins are insignificant. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://heinonline.org/HOL/Page?handle=hein.journals/chiclat26&div=13&id=&page=&collection=journals|title=Redirecting...|website=heinonline.org|accessdate=2018-10-15}}</ref>
== Examples by region == Although much of the literature that has been produced on internalized racism has been confined to the African American experience in the United States, internalized racism is characteristic of systemic racism.<ref name=":0" /> The following is a look at internalized racism in different geographical regions around the world.
=== Native Americans in present day United States === In order to create the nation of the United States on land that was already inhabited, a narrative of native inferiority was often employed to justify their subjugation.<ref name=":6" /> As a result of an overgeneralized picture of native peoples as being defeated and white invaders as victors, internalized racism continues to present itself in Native American communities. Julian Rice notes that apathy towards cultural traditions, self-centeredness, and materialistic obsession could all be seen as a adoption of narratives from the US government or missionaries that emphasized the superior mindset of whiteness.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rice|first=Julian|date=1998|title="It Was Their Own Fault for Being Intractable": Internalized Racism and Wounded Knee|journal=American Indian Quarterly|volume=22|issue=1/2|pages=63–82|jstor=1185108}}</ref> Lisa Poupart adds to these assertions, saying that Native Americans are forced into a "double consciousness," of being simultaneously deprived of past traditions and constantly reminded that those traditions were taken from them. Although she does not seek to use internalized racism to dismiss blame in cases of alcoholism, family violence, and sexual assault, she describes how the combination of stereotypes about the stoic and savage native, the introduction of physical violence to native communities through requiring children to go to boarding schools, and the adoption of white notions of patriarchy combined to create these types of violence and abuses in American Indian communities, where they had been virtually coexistent before European contact.<ref name=":6" /> In the case of alcoholism especially, internalized racism about native inferiority created conditions of dependency on European superiority, leading to the creation of negative stereotypes.
=== Brazil === [[File:Brazilians 001.JPG|thumb|Brazilians of different ethnicities from the end of the 19th century to the very beginning of the 20th century]] Because Brazilians have many different ethnic origins, [[Race and ethnicity in Brazil|race in brazil]] is often conceptualized as a [[racial democracy]]: a system that involves so much interracial marriage and interaction that systemic racism isn't a national problem. However, many scholars actually contest this definition, referring to this idea as "the myth of racial democracy," because prejudice and discrimination based on race is still prevalent.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Bianchi|first=Fernanda T.|last2=Zea|first2=Maria Cecilia|last3=Belgrave|first3=Faye Z.|last4=Echeverry|first4=John J.|date=2002|title=Racial identity and self-esteem among Black Brazilian men: Race matters in Brazil too!|url=http://psycnet.apa.org/getdoi.cfm?doi=10.1037/1099-9809.8.2.157|journal=Cultural Diversity & Ethnic Minority Psychology|volume=8|issue=2|pages=157–169|doi=10.1037//1099-9809.8.2.157|issn=1099-9809}}</ref> Nonetheless, it is important to note that race, as a social construct, has a unique conceptualization in Brazil. As opposed the [[One-drop rule|"one-drop" rule]] employed in the US (i.e. "one-drop" of black blood constitutes a person's blackness), Brazilians recognize a spectrum of race and color-based identities.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Hordge-Freeman|first=Elizabeth|date=October 2013|title=What's love got to do with it?: racial features, stigma and socialization in Afro-Brazilian families|journal=Ethnic and Racial Studies|volume=36|issue=10|pages=1507–1523|doi=10.1080/01419870.2013.788200|issn=0141-9870}}</ref>
The first major instance of internalized racism in Brazil comes out of this spectrum. A 1976 national survey found that there were over 100 colloquial terms in use to describe race-related phenotypes.<ref name=":7" /> Examples of these terms include "black (preto, negro), white (branco), brown or mixed (moreno, mulato), dark (escuro), light (claro), closed (fechado), freckled (sarard), and others."<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Goldstein|first=Donna|date=1999|title="Interracial" Sex and Racial Democracy in Brazil: Twin Concepts?|journal=American Anthropologist|volume=101|issue=3|pages=563–578|jstor=683848}}</ref> The use of various terms for color and race often serves as evidence of the following notions, among others: whiteness is beauty, whiteness is clean, whiteness is successful and blackness is dirty.<ref name=":7" /> Anthropologist Elizabeth Hordge-Freeman found this especially apparent when working with and around pregnant women in a poor and working-class neighborhood in Salvador, Bahia, Brazil. Women expressed a clear desire and preferential treatment for child that were "whiter" in appearance, even engaging in practices of pinching an infant's nose to try to make it smaller.<ref name=":7" /> Many of the women she worked with were racially black, or mixed race.
Additionally, race in Brazil is not confined to physical indicators. Individuals who are black can gain higher economic status and gain recognition as "white" or "whitened" by both black and white Brazilians alike.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=ROLAND|first=L. KAIFA|date=2013-07-26|title=T/RACING BELONGING THROUGH CUBAN TOURISM|journal=Cultural Anthropology|volume=28|issue=3|pages=396–419|doi=10.1111/cuan.12011|issn=0886-7356}}</ref> This conflates economic success with whiteness and poverty with blackness, as well as incentivizing the idea of "whitening," whether through "money whiteness" or interracial mixture.<ref name=":8" /> This furthers the incidence of internalized racism by getting Brazilians of all race to have largely positive associations with whiteness and largely negative associations with blackness.<ref name=":8" />
=== Zimbabwe and Swaziland === In a study designed to compare the incidence of internalized racism in a country that underwent direct European colonization (Zimbabwe) and a country that has maintained is pre-colonial monarchy to date (Swaziland), social science researchers investigated the role of historical context and education in internalized racism.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Cort|first=Malcolm A.|last2=Tull|first2=Eugene S.|last3=Gwebu|first3=Keratiloe|last4=Dlamini|first4=Priscilla|last5=Pinkney|first5=Erica|last6=Gramby|first6=Eundene|last7=Cuthbertson|first7=Shanitria|last8=Daniels|first8=Ashley|last9=Luu|first9=Shay|date=December 2009|title=Education and internalized racism in socio-political context: Zimbabwe and Swaziland|url=https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0362331909001104|journal=The Social Science Journal|volume=46|issue=4|pages=644–655|doi=10.1016/j.soscij.2009.08.001|issn=0362-3319|pmc=3151557|pmid=21833155}}</ref> A major motivating factor for this study was the fact that internalized racism has largely gone unstudied in the African continent. The study found that, despite the scholars' hypothesis that Zimbabwe would have more internalized racism, there was no significant difference in internalized racism incidence between the countries. They believe that this is due to the widespread nature of racism systems, which still came into contact with Swaziland through trade relations.<ref name=":10" /> They also found increased education had a significant negative correlation with internalized racism.<ref name=":10" />
=== China === The case of China is of interest because some have argued that racism, and race itself doesn't exist in China.<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Dikötter|first=Frank|date=1994|title=Racial Identities in China: Context and Meaning|journal=The China Quarterly|issue=138|pages=404–412|jstor=654950}}</ref> However, Dutch Historian Frank Dikötter argues that everything from the practice of using cranium weight between races as a measure of white and Chinese superiority to the [[Nanjing anti-African protests|physical attacks and demonstrations of Chinese university students against African students]] make it clear that race is indeed recognized in China.<ref name=":11" /> Indeed the context of race and [[Ethnic issues in China|racism in China]] is heavily affected by the fact that the large majority of the county is identified as Han Chinese (90.56% of the reported population in 2005).<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Han|first=Dong|date=April 2010|title=Policing and racialization of rural migrant workers in Chinese cities|journal=Ethnic and Racial Studies|volume=33|issue=4|pages=593–610|doi=10.1080/01419870903325651|issn=0141-9870}}</ref> 55 minority ethnic groups are recognized by the government, giving the government the power to dictate different groups as legitimate (and therefore eligible for less taxes, more subsidies and less restrictions) or illegitimate. This creates an environments in which groups attempt to gain their validation and sense of worth from the dominant Han Chinese and the state, internalizing a subordinate position. Because this system involves policing of social groups, it also involves discriminatory practices which are then internalized by both recognized and unrecognized minority groups.<ref name=":12" />
== Implications == This section discusses the implications of internalized racism, and why the topic is significant. It should be noted that examples of psychological harm related to internalized racism are not given in attempt to describe internalized racism as product of the psyche of the oppressed. Internalized racism is not defined as a weakness in the minds of the oppressed.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":13" />
=== Health === High scores on internalized racism have been repeatedly correlated with a variety of poor psychological and physical health outcomes among sample populations including African Americans, US-Born Caribbean Blacks, foreign-born Caribbean Blacks, Filipino Americans, non-American Pacific Islanders and multiracial samples of Americans.<ref name=":14" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":13" />
A study conducted by researchers Mouzon and McLean found that there is a positive correlation between internalized racism in black individuals and the state of their mental health, specifically depression and psychological distress. The results showed that African-Americans and US-born Caribbean Blacks embodied more internal racism, and thus experienced poorer mental health than foreign born Caribbean Blacks. <ref name=":14" /> A similar study by researchers Graham and West discovered that anxiety is also correlational to internalized racism in black individuals. This conclusion is significant considering that, “... anxiety disorders have been found to be more persistent in Black American populations as compared to other racial groups.” <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Graham|first=Jessica R.|last2=West|first2=Lindsey M.|last3=Martinez|first3=Jennifer|last4=Roemer|first4=Lizabeth|date=July 2016|title=The mediating role of internalized racism in the relationship between racist experiences and anxiety symptoms in a Black American sample|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26750994|journal=Cultural Diversity & Ethnic Minority Psychology|volume=22|issue=3|pages=369–376|doi=10.1037/cdp0000073|issn=1099-9809|pmid=26750994}}</ref> The same study goes on to describe the methods therapists can take to mitigate the anxiety in black individuals caused by internalized racism, such as rationalizing negative thoughts.
Asian Americans are also subject to internalized racism, and the Internalized Racism in Asian Americans Scale (IRAAS) was created by researchers to determine the extent in which Asian Americans accepted the negative stereotypes about themselves. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Choi|first=Andrew Young|last2=Israel|first2=Tania|last3=Maeda|first3=Hotaka|date=January 2017|title=Development and evaluation of the Internalized Racism in Asian Americans Scale (IRAAS)|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/28068131|journal=Journal of Counseling Psychology|volume=64|issue=1|pages=52–64|doi=10.1037/cou0000183|issn=0022-0167|pmid=28068131}}</ref> This results revealed that there is a correlation between mental health and the degree in which Asian Americans subscribe to the adverse racial stereotypes. These effects include lower self esteem, symptoms of depression, and general psychological distress. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Keum|first=Brian TaeHyuk|last2=Brady|first2=Jennifer L.|last3=Sharma|first3=Rajni|last4=Lu|first4=Yun|last5=Kim|first5=Young Hwa|last6=Thai|first6=Christina J.|date=October 2018|title=Gendered Racial Microaggressions Scale for Asian American Women: Development and initial validation|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/30058827|journal=Journal of Counseling Psychology|volume=65|issue=5|pages=571–585|doi=10.1037/cou0000305|issn=0022-0167|pmid=30058827}}</ref>
For more examples of studies that show significant relations of internalized racism to increased incidence of anxiety and depression, low individual and collective self-esteem, low sense of ethnic identity, lower levels of life satisfaction, higher body fat measures and other measures of psychological distress, please see the [[#Further Reading|Further Reading]] section below. These studies imply that internalized racism subjects the racially oppressed to a wide range of adverse mental and physical health outcomes.<ref name=":14" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":13" />
=== Contributing to systemic racism === In her book, ''What Does It Mean to Be White? Developing White Racial Literacy'', Robin DiAngelo describes the cycle of racism as a [[Feedback|feedback loop]] that uses power, control, and economics to go from (1) systematic mistreatment of a group to creation of misinformation to, (2) societal acceptance of misinformation to, (3) internalized oppression and internalized dominance to, (4) racism perpetuated and enforced by institutions, leading to, (4) justification for further mistreatment.<ref name=":15">{{Cite journal|last=DiAngelo|first=Robin|date=2012|title=Chapter 5: The Cycle of Oppression|journal=Counterpoints|volume=398|pages=65–77|jstor=42981485}}</ref> In other words, internalized racism is involved in reinforcing racism, and ensuring that it continues. It creates a justification for continued mistreatment of the racially subjugated.<ref name=":6" /> Additionally, it can create an acceptance of the status quo, leading some to conclude that racism is not an issue that needs to be addressed.<ref name=":1" /> If members of racially oppressed groups internalize the validity of their own oppression, they have no reason to contest the system. Internalized racism can also be seen as a means of "[[dividing and conquering]]" racially subordinate groups to create conflicts between them and suppress united efforts to contest racism.<ref name=":16">{{Cite journal|last=CHISOM|first=RON|last2=BILLINGS|first2=DAVID|date=2003|title=Overcoming Internalized Racial Oppression: A challenge to the people of color Environmental Justice Movement|journal=Race, Poverty & the Environment|volume=10|issue=1|pages=29–30|jstor=41554368}}</ref>
== Responses == [[File:KAS-Black is beautiful-Bild-5479-2.jpg|thumb|KAS-Black is beautiful-Bild-5479-2]]Many have offered approaches to address internalized racism. Ron Chisom, the co-founder and executive director of The People's Institute for Survival and Beyond in New Orleans, suggests a six-point approach for those who experience internalized racism:<ref name=":16" />
# Analyze internalized racial oppression in its historical and cultural context # Recognize negative messages, and have programs to undo/unlearn them # Learn about how internalized [[racial superiority]] spreads among the racially dominant # Organize with members of other racially oppressed groups # Celebrate community and culture # Support [[community organizing]] and [[leadership development]]<ref name=":16" />
David W. Concepción notes that because confronting internalized oppression often creates a paradox for people having to see themselves as both a victim and perpetrator of that oppression, a major factor in addressing internalized oppression is being able to confront false narratives while at the same time employing self-forgiveness.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Concepción|first=David W.|date=2009|title=Overcoming Oppressive Self-Blame: Gray Agency in Underground Railroads|journal=Hypatia|volume=24|issue=1|pages=81–99|jstor=20618122}}</ref>
Marc Weinblatt and Cheryl Harrison emphasize that one must acknowledge that race is a social category with real implications while at the same time reject the falsehoods behind racist attitudes. Because finding this balance can be difficult, it is often helpful to have separate spaces for those who experience internalized oppression and those who experience internalized privilege. Additionally, Weinblatt makes it clear that there is a need for those with privilege to risk it in order to seek the end of racism.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Weinblatt|first=Marc|last2=Harrison|first2=Cheryl|date=2011|title=CHAPTER TWO: Theatre of the Oppressor: Working with Privilege Toward Social Justice|journal=Counterpoints|volume=416|pages=21–31|jstor=42981325}}</ref>
An example of a movement that considers some of the above considerations is the "[[Black is beautiful|Black is Beautiful]]" movement. These efforts began during the [[Black Power movement|Black Power]] movement in the [[1960s in the United States]]. In order to contest the narratives that blackness was something ugly, inferior and less valuable, members of the Black community began fighting back with advertising and other media campaigns.<ref name=":17" /> The idea behind the movement has persisted to the present day, with social media based movements such as "[[Black Girl Magic]]" and "Black Boy Joy" that aim to celebrate blackness.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/nationnow/la-na-nn-everyones-saying-black-girls-are-magic-20150909-htmlstory.html|title=Why everyone's saying 'Black Girls are Magic' - Los Angeles Times|last=Thomas|first=Dexter|website=latimes.com|accessdate=2018-11-02}}</ref>
== Potential healing for African Americans == Dr. Watts-Jones indicates in her study that there is a possible method in which African Americans can overcome their internalized racism. <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Watts-Jones|first=Dee|date=December 2002|title=Healing Internalized Racism: The Role of a Within-Group Sanctuary Among People of African Descent|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1111/j.1545-5300.2002.00591.x|journal=Family Process|volume=41|issue=4|pages=591–601|doi=10.1111/j.1545-5300.2002.00591.x|issn=0014-7370}}</ref> By finding sanctuary within the African American community, members are able to achieve mental and physical security from their racist environment. Dr. Watts-Jones states that the collective experience of pain in African Americans work in tandem to heal together. However, the process of healing can be extended outside the African American community, by allowing other racial groups to perceive African Americans’ internalized racism as well. In doing so, White people can be utilized as an ally rather than another force of oppression.
