{{Infobox women |image = File:Armenian woman in national costume (crop).jpg |caption = An Armenian woman in national costume poses on a hillside near [[Artvin]] (present-day Turkey), circa 1910. |gii = 0.340 (2012) |gii_rank = 59th |matdeath = 30 (2010) |womparl = 10.7% (2012) |femed = 94.1% (2010) |womlab = 59% (2014)<ref name="worldbank">{{cite web|url=http://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SL.TLF.ACTI.FE.ZS/countries|publisher=data.worldbank.org|title=Labor force participation rate, female (% of female population ages 15-64) (modeled ILO estimate) | Data|accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> | ggg = 0.6634 (2013) | ggg_rank = 94th | ggg_ref = <ref name="ggr">{{cite web|title=The Global Gender Gap Report 2013|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GenderGap_Report_2013.pdf#page=20|publisher=World Economic Forum|pages=12–13}}</ref> }} {{Women in society sidebar}} '''Women in Armenia''' have been officially guaranteed gender equality since the establishment of the Republic of [[Armenia]] in 1991. This has enabled women to actively participate in all spheres of Armenian life. Armenian women have attained prominence in entertainment, politics and other fields.
==Work and business== [[File:Armenka.jpg|thumbnail|left|Painting of an Armenian woman (circa 1682)]] According to the 2011 [[Grant Thornton International]] business survey, 29% of top-level managerial positions in Armenia were occupied by women in 2010. However, this figure declined to 23% in 2011. Based on a report by the [[United Nations]], there were 24 female mayors and community leaders in Armenia in 2011; a further 50 women held lower-level administrative positions.<ref name=Arka>[http://www.arka.am/eng/economy/2011/03/12/24553.html Survey: Women In Armenia Forced Out From The Positions Of Top-Managers]. Economy: Arka News Agency.</ref>
==Traditional status== Although some nationalist feminists from the early 20th century to the present have concocted a view of ancient Armenian society and law as being woman-friendly, there is virtually no evidence for this assertion.<ref name="google">{{cite book|title=A History of Armenian Women's Writing, 1880-1922|author=Rowe, V.|date=2003|publisher=Cambridge Scholars|isbn=9781904303237|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mOvE4Ec-_oEC&pg=PA86|page=86|accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> The law code of Mkhitar Gos, dating to the 12th century, sought to raise women's status from its former level, however the code explicitly enshrined male domination and forbade divorce, even in the case of domestic violence or [[marital rape]].<ref name="google2">{{cite book|title=The Political Economy of Human Rights in Armenia: Authoritarianism and Democracy in a Former Soviet Republic|author=Payaslian, S.|date=2011|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=9780857731692|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nqv3AgAAQBAJ&pg=PA55|page=55|accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> Its most progressive elements seem to have never been applied in society at large, and in the 18th and 19th centuries both outsider and insider reports overwhelmingly commented on the low status of women in traditional Armenian society. Married women lived as virtual slaves of their husbands' families, although the situation improved gradually with age.<ref name="everyculture">{{cite web|url=http://www.everyculture.com/Russia-Eurasia-China/Armenians-Marriage-and-Family.html|publisher=everyculture.com|title=Marriage and family - Armenians|accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref> During the first year of marriage, they were not permitted to speak to anyone except their husband, and were forbidden from leaving the house. In some villages, these restrictions continued even after the birth of the first child, and may have lasted more than ten years. Female suicide was more common than male suicide, in striking contrast to the situation in the west.<ref name="google3">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AC4BAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA151|title=The earth and its inhabitants. The universal geography, ed. by E.G. Ravenstein (A.H. Keane).|author1=Reclus, J.J.É.|first=|author2=Ravenstein, E.G.|author3=Keane, A.H.|date=1878|publisher=J.S. Virtue|year=|isbn=|location=|page=151|pages=|accessdate=22 June 2018}}</ref>
In spite of the inferior position of women in Armenian society, the [[Armenian Apostolic Church]] allowed women greater opportunities for assuming clerical roles than most other Christian traditions. Unlike the Eastern Orthodox, however, they were strongly opposed to divorce, and as a result the divorce rate in traditional Armenia has always been among the lowest in the Christian world.
==Violence against women== According to the [[World Health Organization]], between 10% and 60% of Armenian women suffered [[domestic violence|domestic abuse and violence]] in 2002; the uncertainty of the data was due to the underreporting of domestic violence in Armenia. Underreporting is said to occur because of the treatment of domestic violence as a private family matter.<ref name=UHRC/> There are no well-established laws against domestic aggression and gender-based prejudice in Armenia. Furthermore, divorcing a husband – even an abusive one – causes "social disgrace", with the families of women who file for divorce or report domestic violence being considered to be shamed. Other contributing factors include Armenian women's lack of, or lower level of, education regarding their rights and how to protect themselves from abuse.<ref name="UHRC">[http://www.unitedhumanrights.org/2010/05/domestic-violence-against-women-in-armenia Domestic Violence Against Women in Armenia]. United Human Rights Council (UHRC). 26 May 2010.</ref>
==Political status== In May 2007, through the legislative decree known as "the gender quota law", more Armenian women were encouraged to get involved in politics. That year, only seven women occupied parliamentary positions. Among these female politicians was [[Hranush Hakobyan]], the longest-serving woman in the [[National Assembly of Armenia]].<ref name=WNO/> The relative lack of women in Armenia's government has led to Armenian women being considered "among the most underrepresented" and "among the lowest in the world" by foreign observers.<ref name="WNO">Itano, Nicole. [http://www.womensenews.org/story/the-world/070510/quota-law-puts-more-women-armenias-election Quota Law Puts More Women in Armenia's Election]. WeNews. 10 May 2007.</ref> In addition, Armenian women's place in politics is often located in the private sphere. Often their entry in the public sphere is only valued when they reflect the image of the feminine ideal based on social expectations, which continue to put a barrier on the political, social, and economic accessibility for women.<ref>Beukian, Sevan, 2014, Motherhood as Armenianness: Expressions of Femininity in the Making of Armenian National Identity, Studies in Ethnicity and Nationalism, 14 (2):247-269</ref> In 2015, [[Arpine Hovhannisyan]] became the first Armenian Woman to hold the position of Justice Minister in Armenia, a role she held until 2017.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://asbarez.com/139532/arpine-hovhannisyan-appointed-justice-minister-of-armenia/|title=Arpine Hovhannisyan Appointed Justice Minister of Armenia|last=|first=|date=4 September 2015|work=Asbarez|access-date=22 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.tert.am/en/news/2017/05/17/arpine-hovhannisyan/2374503|title=Armenia's justice minister sacked|last=|first=|date=17 May 2015|work=Tert.am|access-date=22 June 2018}}</ref> Hovhannisyan is also a politician and lawyer.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.parliament.am/deputies.php?sel=details&ID=1158&lang=eng|title=Arpine Hovhannisyan|last=|first=|date=|website=National Assembly of the Republic of Armenia|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=22 June 2018}}</ref>
==Health and welfare== In 2010 and 2011, during Women’s Month and as part of the "For You, Women" charitable program, the Surb Astvatcamayr Medical Center in the Armenian capital of [[Yerevan]] offered free [[gynecological]] and surgical services to the women of Armenia for a full month. Women from across the country arrived seeking treatment.<ref name=Epress>[http://www.epress.am/en/2011/03/11/women-in-armenia-to-receive-free-medical-treatment-for-one-month/ Women in Armenia to Receive Free Medical Treatment for One Month]. Epress.am. March 11, 2011.</ref>
==Sex selective abortion== [[Sex selective abortion]] is reported as being a problem in the country, due to patriarchal social norms which consider having a son preferable to having a daughter.<ref name="bbc">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-16248511|publisher=bbc.com|title=Fears grow over Caucasus selective abortions of girls - BBC News|accessdate=2017-03-03}}</ref><ref>https://www.irex.org/sites/default/files/2012-2013%20STG%20Scholar%20Research%20Brief%20-Final.pdf</ref><ref name=teconomist>[https://www.economist.com/news/europe/21586617-son-preference-once-suppressed-reviving-alarmingly-gendercide-caucasus Gendercide in the Caucasus] The Economist (September 13, 2013)</ref><ref>Michael, M; King, L; Guo, L; McKee, M; Richardson, E; Stuckler, D (2013), [http://researchonline.lshtm.ac.uk/1130041/1/3909713.pdf The mystery of missing female children in the Caucasus: an analysis of sex ratios by birth order], International perspectives on sexual and reproductive health, 39 (2), pp. 97-102, {{ISSN|1944-0391}}</ref><ref name="John Bongaarts 2013 pages 185">[[John Bongaarts]] (2013), The Implementation of Preferences for Male Offspring, Population and Development Review, Volume 39, Issue 2, pages 185–208, June 2013</ref> Nevertheless, due to strong emigration under the form of "[[brain drain]]", where young Armenian men go abroad in search of work, there are more young women than men in the country, especially among those in their 20s: women make up 55.8% of the population aged 15–29.<ref>http://www.un.am/up/library/Labor%20Market_Armenia_eng.pdf</ref>
==Literature== {{Main|Armenian literature}} The oldest literary expression by Armenian women available to us today in writing is the poetry of two 8th-century CE women, [[Khosrovidukht]] of [[Goghtn]] and [[Sahakdukht]] of [[Syunik (historic province)|Syunik]].<ref>{{cite book |title=The Other Voice: Armenian Women's Poetry Through the Ages | place=Boston | publisher=AIWA Press, Armenian International Women's Association | ISBN=0964878747 | last=Der-Hovanessian | first=Diana }}</ref> Following the Armenian literary renaissance of the 19th century, and the spread of educational opportunities for women, a number of other writers emerged, among them the 19th-century feminist writer [[Srpouhi Dussap]], considered the first female Armenian novelist.<ref name=MAL>''Արդի հայ գրականութիւն'' (''Modern Armenian Literature''). [[Beirut]]. pp. 134-138.</ref> She, like her contemporary, [[Zabel Sibil Asadour]], is generally associated with Constantinople and the Western Armenian literary tradition. [[Zabel Yesayan]], also born in Constantinople, bridged the gap with Eastern Armenian literature by settling in Soviet Armenia in 1933. The literary renaissance and its accompanying voice of protest also had its representatives in the East with poet [[Shushanik Kurghinian]](1876–1927) of Aleksandrapol (today, Gyumri). [[Sylvia Kaputikyan]] and [[Maro Markarian]] are probably the best-known women poets from the Republic of Armenia of the 20th century, and continued the tradition of political speech through poetry.
==Notable Armenian women== ;Notable Queens and Princesses *[[Erato of Armenia|Erato]], Roman client Queen from 10 BC until 2 BC with her brother-husband King [[Tigranes IV]] *[[Ashkhen]], wife of [[Tiridates III of Armenia]] *[[Isabella, Queen of Armenia|Isabella]], Queen of [[Cilician Armenia]] (1219–1252) ;Modern Armenian women *[[Zabel Yesayan]] (1878–1943), novelist, translator *[[Silva Kaputikyan]] (1919–2006), one of the best-known Armenian writers of the 20th century<ref>{{cite journal|author=Editorial Board|title=Սիլվա Կապուտիկյան [Silva Kaputikyan]|journal=[[Patma-Banasirakan Handes]]|date=2006|issue=2|pages=328–329|url=http://hpj.asj-oa.am/1684/|language=hy}}</ref> *[[Gohar Gasparyan]] (1924–2007), opera singer *[[Lusine Zakaryan]] (1937–1992), soprano *[[Galya Novents]] (1937–2012), stage and film actress *[[Hasmik Papian]] (born 1961), soprano *[[Zaruhi Postanjyan]] (born 1972), politician, activist, member of parliament *[[Nazik Avdalyan]] (born 1986), weightlifter, World champion *[[Susianna Kentikian]] (born 1987), professional boxer, former World Flyweight Champion *[[Iveta Mukuchyan]] (born 1986), singer-songwriter, model, and actress ;Diaspora Armenian women (full Armenian ancestry) *[[Diana Abgar]] (1859-1937), Armenian writer, diplomat, and ambassador to Japan of [[First Republic of Armenia]] *[[Aurora Mardiganian]] (1901-1994), author, actress, [[Armenian Genocide]] surviror *[[Kay Armen]] (1915–2011), Armenian American singer *[[Irene Zazians]] (1927–2012), Iranian actress *[[Sylvie Vartan]] (born 1944), Bulgarian-born French singer and actress *[[Kim Kashkashian]] (born 1952), Grammy-award-winning American violist *[[Angela Sarafyan]] (born 1983), Armenian American actress *[[Tatev Abrahamyan]] (born 1988), Armenian-born American chess Grandmaster
;Notable women with partial Armenian ancestry *[[Cher]] (born 1946), American singer *[[Stephanie (singer)|Stephanie]] (born 1987), Japanese singer-songwriter *[[Anna Der-Vartanian]] (born 1920) first female Master Chief Petty Officer the history of United States Navy *[[Sian Elias]] (born 13 March 1949) chief justice of New Zealand
==See also== *[[Mother Armenia]] *[[Politics of Armenia]] *[[Crime in Armenia]] *[[Union of Producers and Women]] *[[Armenia women's national football team]]
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

[[File:Yersin Museum (Nha Trang).jpg|thumb|Yersin Museum in Nha Trang, Vietnam]] The '''Yersin Museum''' is a [[museum]] in [[Nha Trang]], [[Vietnam]]. It is dedicated to [[Alexandre Yersin]] the [[bacteriologist]].
It is located on 8 - 10 Tran Phu boulevard in the former home of Yersin in the enclosure of the Pasteur Institute.<ref>[http://nhatrang.online.fr/sections.php?op=viewarticle&artid=44 Nhatrang.online]</ref>
The museum contains a large collection of Yersin's equipment and letters as well as giving a description of his contributions to bacteriology and science generally. The captions are in French but English and Vietnamese translations are provided. It is open from 8am until 11am and 2pm until 4.30pm weekdays and closed on saturdays and sundays. Entry fee is VD 26,000 for adults.
==References== {{reflist}} * [http://pasteur-nhatrang.org.vn/pages/chitiet.aspx* Bảo tàng Dr. A.Yersin]

'''Youth in Guatemala''' are the largest segment of the nation's population. Youth includes individuals between the ages of 15 and 24<ref name=":1" /> Over half of the population is under 19 years old in 2011,<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|title = Statistics|url = http://www.unicef.org/infobycountry/guatemala_statistics.html|website = UNICEF|accessdate = 2015-10-25|language = en-US}}</ref> the highest proportion of young people of any country in Latin America.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Guatemala: Beyond the Early Phase of the Demographic Transition|url = http://www.prb.org/publications/datasheets/2011/world-population-data-sheet/guatemala.aspx|website = www.prb.org|accessdate = 2015-12-01}}</ref> The health, education, and work opportunities for young people differ by ethnicity (''[[Ladino people|ladino]]'' or [[Indigenous peoples of Guatemala|indigenous]]) and social class.
Male [[literacy]] rate is 89.3% and the female literacy rate is 85.6%.<ref name=":1" /> Secondary education participation is around 17%.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last1 = Bonilla|first1 = Kleinsy|last2 = Kwak|first2 = Jae Sung|title = Challenges of Highly Educated Human Resources in Guatemala|journal = Asian Journal of Latin American Studies|pages = 17–43|accessdate = }}</ref> 30.3% of youth are married by the age of 18.<ref name=":1" />
Poverty and inequality affect a youth's access to healthcare.<ref name=":2">{{cite web|title = World Health Organization|website = http://www.who.int/countryfocus/cooperation_strategy/ccsbrief_gtm_en.pdf?ua=1|accessdate = 8 October 2015}}</ref> Females experience less access to health care and education than males.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|title = Meet The 15-Year-Old From Rural Guatemala Who Addressed The U.N.|url = https://www.npr.org/sections/goatsandsoda/2015/03/12/392174520/meet-the-15-year-old-from-rural-guatemala-who-addressed-the-u-n|website = NPR.org|accessdate = 2015-10-25}}</ref> The lack of adequate nutrition and health care in [[Guatemala#Health|Guatemala]] has adverse effects on a youth's overall health. One example being stunted growth of half of the Guatemalan youth.<ref name=":1" /> The [[Millennium Development Goals]] works to these inequalities and barriers.
Vulnerable youths who are at-risk for joining a gang are males between the ages of living in marginalized urban areas and have limited access to education.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://pdf.usaid.gov/pdf_docs/Pnadg834.pdf|title = Central America and Mexico Gang Assessment|date = |accessdate = |website = USAID|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> A program called Open Schools combats forces that push youth into dangerous situations and works to overcome barriers that Guatemalan youth face.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|url = |title = Open Schools|last = Magnifico|first = Claudio|date = November 2011|journal = Americas|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> [[File:Guatemala0913.JPG|thumb|Community village school]]
== Education ==
[[Education in Guatemala]] has less than full participation. Primary schools do not achieve 100% enrollment and from there, enrollment drops until it reaches about 17% at the high school level.<ref name=":0" /> Females are less represented, with 44.3% net enrollment ratio, compared to males at 48%.<ref name=":1" /> This contributes to a higher participation in the informal market.
Guatemala's public university is USAC, [[Universidad de San Carlos de Guatemala]]. "From every 100 graduate students enrolled in San Carlos of Guatemala University only 13 successfully completed their programs".<ref name=":0" /> Youth who successfully complete secondary education typically obtain a degree in the social sciences, with 1334 social science master's degrees granted of the 2093 total degrees.<ref name=":0" /> The medical field, as well as [[Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics]] fields, should be a top priority but are not a focus of higher education. Social connections and ties, as well as [[nepotism]], are viewed as more important than Education.<ref name=":0" />
Teachers in Guatemala often encounter youth who were left behind by their parents who migrated elsewhere.<ref name=":6">{{cite journal|last1 = Lykes|first1 = M. Brinton|last2 = Erin|first2 = Sibley|title = Exploring Meaning-Making With Adolescents 'Left Behind' By Migration|journal = Educational Action Research|date = 2013|pages = 565–581|doi = 10.1080/09650792.2013.832346}}</ref> They often dissuaded their students from migrating due to loss of human capital experienced during migration.<ref name=":6" />
Open Schools, a program launched in 2008, helps prevent violence and protect youth by providing them opportunity to constructively use their free time.<ref name=":8" /><ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url = http://www.unicef.org/guatemala/english/children_18033.htm|title = The Children - Primary School Years|date = |accessdate = |website = UNICEF Guatemala|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Open Schools is not a formal educational environment but it aims to help youth who are disadvantaged through culture, art, sports, and technology.<ref name=":8" /> Open Schools program is available to students on the weekends where youth can socialize and participate in constructive activities.<ref name=":9" /> [[Child Aid]] is another program that helps a youth's educational experience by increasing literacy.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://child-aid.org/our-program/reading-for-life-overview/|title = Literacy Program Overview|date = |accessdate = |website = Child Aid|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref>
== Employment == 140,000 Guatemalan youth enter the labor market each year.<ref name=":0" /> About 25,000 of those youth gain access to formal employment. Formal employment is often classified as training for the job and social security.<ref name=":0" /> It is estimated that jobs in the informal market have reached about 5.1 million.<ref name=":0" /> Youth who obtain a degree are not properly utilized in the formal job market, as they are outcompeted by their foreign counterparts.<ref name=":0" /> Work after graduation is limited because it is assumed that youth who hold degrees would not be willing to work low paying jobs.
Within the public sector, youth are discouraged from participation in the workforce because of poor salaries and disincentives.<ref name=":0" /> Youth often enter into the [[Informal sector|informal job market]] at a young age, sometimes dropping out of school to support themselves or their families. Informal jobs provide youth with income but are untaxed and unmonitored by the state, examples being farmers or domestic workers.<ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url = http://www.globalfairness.org/attachments/article/40/PILAR_Roadmap_Eng.pdf|title = Roadmap to Economic Formalization|date = |accessdate = |website = Global Fairness Initiative|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref name=":11">{{Cite news|url = http://www.globalpost.com/dispatch/news/regions/americas/120702/informal-economy-swallows-latin-american-workers|title = Informal economy swallows Latin American workers|last = Otis|first = John|date = July 3, 2012|work = |access-date = |via = }}</ref> These jobs do not provide youth or other individuals with government protections, like insurance.<ref name=":11" /> PILAR, a program which stands for Promoting Informal Labor Rights, works to provide more protection for those in the informal sector.<ref name=":10" />
Open Schools provides leadership training and job training to both youth and adults to help ensure steady income and employment.<ref name=":8" />
The [[Millennium Development Goals]], or MDG's, targets causes of poverty such as gender inequality, education, and environmental stability.<ref name=":12">{{Cite web|url = http://www.unmillenniumproject.org/goals/|title = MDGs|date = |accessdate = |website = Millennium Project|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> "Education and training in business administration and large-scale marketing operations are essential for the youth to join the economic life of the country".<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Assessing the Cost to Guatemala of Blocking Indigenous Peoples' Full Economic Participation|last = Varela-Garcia|first = Fabiola|date = 2014|journal = Social Policy|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> MDG's purpose is to prevent youth from entering into poverty by providing educational and economic stability.[[File:US Navy 110503-N-QD416-154 Lt. Patricia Salazar examines a patient's eyes at a Continuing Promise 2011 medical clinic.jpg|thumb|Continuing Promise mission in the Guatemalan community]]
== Health == Emelin, a 13-year-old female, spoke at the United Nations in March 2015 and emphasized the need for health care in her community.<ref name=":3" /> A majority of Guatemalans pay for their health costs out-of-pocket, creating unequal access to services.<ref name=":2" /> She said, "The biggest problems we face as adolescents in my community are early pregnancy, [child]birth, sexual violation and lack of education and health care".<ref name=":3" /> 20% of female adolescents and 24% of male adolescents have a comprehensive knowledge of HIV.<ref name=":1" /> 14.3% of females living in rural areas have a comprehensive knowledge of HIV and 31.5% of females living in urban areas have a comprehensive knowledge of HIV.<ref name=":1" /> In Guatemala, there is little contraception awareness and use among Youth.<ref name=":13">{{Cite web|url = https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/gt.html|title = People and Society: Guatemala|date = |accessdate = |website = The World Factbook|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> Guatemala has the highest fertility rate in Latin America even with half of its population under the age of 19.<ref name=":13" />
A mission called Continuing Promise works to provide health care and community assistance to Latin American youth.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.southcom.mil/newsroom/Pages/Continuing-Promise-2015.aspx|title = Continuing Promise 2015 {{!}} USNS Comfort mission to Latin America & Caribbean|date = |accessdate = |website = United States Southern Command|publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> [[File:Young men in rehabilitation program Guatemala.jpg|thumb|Guatemalan youth in rehabilitation program]]
==Violence== [[Crime in Guatemala]] is one issue facing youth. Guatemala has one of the highest [[homicide]] rates in the world and lies within one of the most dangerous regions of the hemisphere - [[Central America]].<ref name=":4">{{cite journal|last1 = Brenneman|first1 = Robert|title = Wrestling The Devil.|journal = Latin American Research Review|pages = 112–128}}</ref> Violence most often emerges in the presence of gangs and drug trafficking, promoting crimes such as theft and kidnapping. "Gang youth are widely perceived to be the single most important contributors to violence and insecurity in Central American cities".<ref name=":4" /> Guatemalan youth struggle with transitions out of a gang to a more stable environment. The Evangelical-Pentecostal religion provides hope to Guatemalan youth, attempting to exit gangs, through conversion.<ref name=":4" />
In [[Religion in Guatemala|Guatemala]], the Evangelical-Protestant Church receives funding from [[United States Agency for International Development]] to help at-risk youth. The funding is used to help correct structural factors that push delinquent youth into gang participation.<ref name=":4" /> The ties within the Church provide youth with social capital and connections that may aid in seeking employment.
A great risk of death exists for youth attempting to exit Guatemalan gangs. Religious organizations believe that the root causes of gang participation are "poverty, weak schools, and unemployment".<ref name=":4" />
Youth participation in violence has become normalized.<ref name=":7">{{cite journal|last1 = Winton|first1 = Ailsa|title = Youth, Gangs And Violence: Analysing The Social and Spatial Mobility Of Young People In Guatemala City|journal = Children's Geographies|pages = 167–184|doi = 10.1080/14733280500161537}}</ref> While reliable data regarding crime is sparse, there are widespread fears of crime facing Guatemalan youth. "Maras [gangs] are generally associated with low-income urban areas, due to high levels of inequality and the lack of social, economic and cultural alternatives available in this context",<ref name=":7" /> making [[Guatemala City]] one of the most dangerous areas in Guatemala. Gangs dominate public space, often limiting areas where others can interact. An estimated 53-330 gangs reside in Guatemala City.
Gangs can provide youth with a sense of identity. Youths gain a large amount of [[social capital]] in their participation in gangs, making gangs attractive and luring for youth who lack resources.<ref name=":7" /> Youth male gang members who are often the perpetrators of violence also fear for their own safety within the gang.<ref name=":7" /> Young men in gangs are threatened by members of their affiliated gang and sometimes victims of violence within the gang.<ref name=":7" />
Open Schools works to help at risk youth by providing alternatives to participation in gangs.<ref name=":8" />
==Migration== A youth's parents may leave home and migrate to coastal areas or other countries where education and health services are more comprehensive.<ref name=":6" /> Parents also migrate to the United States, Mexico, and Canada to support their family and search of economic opportunity.<ref name=":13" /> Political corruption and violence are factors that cause a parent to leave their child or children with other caretakers.<ref name=":6" /> Youth left behind feel guilt for their parents' sacrifice and often leave school to find work. "9% of children living in migrant households receiving remittances dropped out of school".<ref name=":6" /> Adverse effects on youth of parents migrating include: insecurity, drug use, sexual promiscuity, anxiety, and loneliness.<ref name=":6" />
Youth whose parents migrated to the United States often defend them, saying, "they are not criminals, because they are going to search for a better life for their family members",<ref name=":6" /> normalizing their experience. Guatemalan youth see the allure of moving to various other areas as economic incentives but the threats of violence and deportation as well as loss of social capital dissuade many youth from migrating.
